This is really interesting stuff!

Did you use my HyperNEAT implementation =
or are you rolling your own?  
If you used mine, did you have any trouble g=
etting it to work?  If 
you used your own, are you going to publish some so=
urce code?

P.S. Where do you get 3d humanoid physics models from?



--- I=
n neat@yahoogroups.com, "petar_chervenski" 
<petar_chervenski@...> wrote:
>=

> Hello there, 
> 
> I am using the following CPPN model for the substrate=
: 
> 
> Inputs: X1, Y1, X2, Y2, BIAS
> Outputs: Weight, Node-Bias, Node-Tim=
e_Constant
> 
> The time constant range is [0.5 .. 5.0] and the weight/node=
-bias 
range 
> within the substrate in [-8.0 .. 8.0]. 
> The weight range =
in the CPPN is unbounded. 
> 
> The node-specific outputs are computed usin=
g (X1, Y1, BIAS) and the 
> others set to 0.
> 
> The activation functions =
used are plain sigmoid, gaussian, and 
sine. 
> The CTRNN substrate activat=
es with 0.02 timestep and it is used to 
> control a 3D humanoid model, sim=
ulated in a physical environment 
(using 
> Open Dynamics Engine http://www=
.ode.org ). 
> 
> The thing I notice, is the following: 
> 
> The first net=
works are simple, and so the connective patterns are. 
But 
> the node bias=
es and time constants are also simple. When I watch an 
> animaion of the a=
ctivation changing in the substrate, it looks like 
it 
> exibits a pattern=
. The simplest I've seen can be described as a 
mexican 
> wave travelling =
across the hidden nodes. 
> As the CPPNs complexify, so do the activity pat=
terns exibited. When 
> using regular NEAT for the problem of keeping the h=
umanoid model 
> balanced, it has moslty erratic behaviour, and the lucky o=
nes (with 
> high fitness) usually find a way to trick the system and stay =
in a 
> balanced position forever, without moving at all. 
> But when Hyper=
NEAT is used for this, it looks really interesting 
and.. 
> natural! The m=
odel is trying to balance using its arms, and it is 
> moving.. It looks li=
ke a drunk guy, but you note the difference. 
> I've arranged the nodes in =
a geometric way.. Let me explain - the 
left 
> and right arm's outputs are=
 separated in the left and right in the 
> substrate space, and close to ea=
ch other. So do the legs. The 
hidden 
> nodes are in the center in a star/=
cirlular shape. I also included 3 
> inputs (head velocity) in the center a=
round 0.0, but with smaller 
> radius than the ring of hidden nodes. 
> 
> =
Peter
>
